body_html:
See this for generating a timeline with memory usage: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/core/profiler#visualize-time-and-memory You can do profiling without ProfileContext, using the old way. If you are using high-level API, you might need to do some hacks to get the RunMetadata https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/profiler/g3doc/command_line.md#command-line-inputs
…
On Tue, Sep 5, 2017 at 6:33 PM, qianyizhang ***@***.***> wrote: @panyx0718 <https://github.com/panyx0718> Thanks for you info, you are correct that I am using the pip install on windows, and it's not a easy task to build from source. Fortunately with the rapid development and recent change in namespace t seems this feature will be open to test in the next patch or so ;-) In the meanwhile, is there a good way to measure to GPU memory usage? (nvidia-smi.exe monitor report is highly inaccurate) And is there any trick of memory optimization (eg. maxnet has force_mirroring to force in-place calculation, https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-memonger) — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub <#12493 (comment)>, or mute the thread <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ACwQe5yxZyHUZcaEKRFDdXOAN8FLU-wuks5sffZ6gaJpZM4O-pcL> .
-- Thanks Xin
body_text:
See this for generating a timeline with memory usage:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/core/profiler#visualize-time-and-memory

You can do profiling without ProfileContext, using the old way. If you are
using high-level API, you might need to do some hacks to get the RunMetadata
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/profiler/g3doc/command_line.md#command-line-inputs

…
On Tue, Sep 5, 2017 at 6:33 PM, qianyizhang ***@***.***> wrote:
 @panyx0718 <https://github.com/panyx0718>
 Thanks for you info, you are correct that I am using the pip install on
 windows, and it's not a easy task to build from source. Fortunately with
 the rapid development and recent change in namespace t seems this feature
 will be open to test in the next patch or so ;-)

 In the meanwhile, is there a good way to measure to GPU memory usage?
 (nvidia-smi.exe monitor report is highly inaccurate)
 And is there any trick of memory optimization (eg. maxnet has
 force_mirroring to force in-place calculation,
 https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-memonger)

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.

Xin
body:
See this for generating a timeline with memory usage:
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/tree/master/tensorflow/core/profiler#visualize-time-and-memory

You can do profiling without ProfileContext, using the old way. If you are
using high-level API, you might need to do some hacks to get the RunMetadata
https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/master/tensorflow/core/profiler/g3doc/command_line.md#command-line-inputs

On Tue, Sep 5, 2017 at 6:33 PM, qianyizhang <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> windows, and it's not a easy task to build from source. Fortunately with
> the rapid development and recent change in namespace t seems this feature
> will be open to test in the next patch or so ;-)

> In the meanwhile, is there a good way to measure to GPU memory usage?
> (nvidia-smi.exe monitor report is highly inaccurate)
> And is there any trick of memory optimization (eg. maxnet has
> force_mirroring to force in-place calculation,
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-memonger)
>
> —
